Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2009 02:28PM Torona wrote: I am now on 8 days post chemo #1 and finally feel a little more normal.  But I have a new development.  I noticed my lumpectomy breast was sore & tender last night when turning over in bed and this morning when I was dressing I noticed my entire nipple area and below was red and angry looking, not hot but warm to touch.  It scared me to death and I immediately called my Nurse Navigator who asked me to come into the bs office to have the nurse look at it. Postoperatively, I did have a huge hematoma that took almost 3 weeks to go down, so now the bs thinks I have an infection from the residual hematoma.   He gave me a script for Clindamycin 300 mg 4 times a day for 20 days!!  I'm wondering if this will interfere with my chemo among other things. Anyone else have something similar happen?  I am concerned and would love to hear from someone.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2009 04:19PM Torona wrote: Thanks so much Virginia.  It's good to know that you felt well enough to drive.  I don't have a long drive at all and I do have some really good friends that will see that I get home safely. I am worried about the after affects. I am a very independent person and don't like having to ask for help or accept it.  I'm better at it since I had a really bad time last summer with 2 back surgeries followed by a postop infection and was really bed-ridden. My mom stayed with me 2 months and I hate to put her through this, too!  I guess God was preparing me for something bigger!  I have been encouraged by this thread and feel that I can do it! Lisa, I feel exactly the same way - that the chemo makes me feel like a cancer patient now.  I am terrified of the se's and I am upset about the hair thing!  Didn't think it would bother me that much. Hope to stay tuned to this thread and learn more.  Thanks!

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2009 04:29PM Torona wrote: I attended the Look Good Feel Better program today and found it so helpful and therapeutic.  The class leader was a cosmetologist who also owns a hair salon and sells wigs.  I went back to her salon and we tried several styles and colors and she helped me find the best ones for me and matched my color.  She is ordering 2 for me to try and then she will help with shaping it and also cutting mine in preparation for my 1st chemo on Thursday 9-17.  I felt a lot better about it afterwards.  I was very impressed at how good they really look and I'm trying to stay positive.  Good luck to us all this week getting our tx.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2009 07:08PM Torona wrote: I am anxious but okay about getting started tomorrow.  Just picked up my new custom fitted wig from the cosmetologist at the LGFB and it looks great - just like my hair now (only better)! I have been reading furiously all the info. I can to be prepared and based on an earlier recommendation about a great book, I ordered "Breast Cancer: Real Questions, Real Answers" by Dr. David Chan. Just wanted to share what he says in his book about some of the subjects discussed here earlier: Cold caps - "don't try to prevent or reduce hair loss by using an ice cap to reduce blood flow to your scalp during chemo.  There have been reports of cancer recurring within the scalp from use of this technique." Fluids - with Cytoxan "you can avoid bladder irritation by drinking 2 quarts of fluid after the Cytoxan infusion is complete and urinating every hour until you go to bed." This amount of fluid/urinating has to be done on each day of your Cytoxan treatment only and not throughout the week.  He recommends Gatorade-type drinks because they have a good electrolyte balance.  He also cautions not to OVERDO fluid intake because taking too much fluid can make you ill by lowering sodium levels in your blood.  Just wanted to share what I read - not sure until I live through it whether it works or not! Good luck to all 4 of us tomorrow, Sanaisa, Brie and Anita. Hope we have good news to report the next couple of days!
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Had a pretty good day today, no nausea just the icky feeling and head being dopy!  It is tolerable now if I don't have more pop up.   Hope you all have a good night!

Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2009 06:59PM - edited Sep 17, 2009 07:00PM by Torona I made it!  Was not too bad and I had the most unbelieveable peace and calm about it all day. Turns out all my family/friends have been praying for me all day - so that was it! Feel fine - just a little woozy from the Ativan (kinda drunk) but no nausea, heartburn or other ailments at this time.  Interestingly, have had the hiccups twice.  I know the se's will take a few days to kick in but so far, the dread of the 1st treatment of T/C is over and I'm good.!  Hopefully, I won't have too many to deal with!  I hope you girls did okay, too!  The next few days will tell.  Hang in there (all of us)!  Get my Neulasta shot tomorrow so I'll get out my Claritin for sure!  More to report after that!
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2009 03:08AM Torona wrote: Scoobydoo, I'll be thinking of you on Thursday, too!  Nice to know we have partners in this horrendous battle of ours.  Where are you located?  I am in Georgia.  I went wig shopping today and it wasn't as bad as I thought it would be. Expected to have my 1st meltdown - instead, had a surprisingly enjoyable time trying on a couple and I bought a really cute one.  My insurance will pay up to $250.00.  Still don't know how I will handle the falling out vs shaving thing. Thought seriously about going ahead and shaving now and start wearing it! Guess I'll wait and see. Got all my meds from the pharmacy today and I did get Emend (really expensive but hopefully will be worth it), Ativan, Decadron, Zofran along with all the other OTC meds mentioned in the chemo list.  Found everything except a satin pillow case - anyone have ideas about where to look? BTW, my onc said definitely get the flu shot - I will as soon as it's available.  I work in a hospital and we can get one free.  Also have an appt. Monday for the "Look Good Feel Better" class so looking forward to free makeup kit!  We need some special treatment after all we've been through! Thanks to everyone for this forum to express ourselves, our fears and concerns. It has really helped me and I have learned from each of you. Hang tough!!!

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2009 06:31PM Torona wrote: Day #2 post chemo -Rough day for me - woke up nauseated and it progressed fairly quickly despite taking the Emend, Zofran, & Decadron. Went in for my Neulasta shot and had to get fluids, Kytril & Ativan.  Not much relief - slept off & on this afternoon but I'm still very nauseated.  Unable to eat or drink but trying small sips ginger ale and crackers. Dr. and office staff puzzled at degree of nausea so soon and the fact I had so much meds yesterday! Boy, don't know how I'm going to handle this!!  Barely hanging on!!
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2009 04:29PM Torona wrote: Hey, I'm still here.  Had a rough last week with the sudden postop lumpectomy infection from a HUGE residual hematoma but the antibiotic is working and not making me sick.  I finally turned the corner on Saturday and have felt really good ever since. I went to work Monday and have been working full days and still feel great!  No se's to speak of except the hair thing.  It's day 15 post tx and it's still hanging on.  My scalp has been hurting the last day or two so it'll probably all be gone by the weekend.  I'm ready with 2 wigs and a few hats & scarves I ordered on internet.  Hope everyone is doing okay.  I can't believe how good I feel and wish it would last.  My next tx is Oct. 8 but feel renewed now to face it more educated this time.  Planning to do some cooking this weekend of things I could eat after tx.  That was really hard for me!  Good luck, girls!

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2009 04:28PM - edited Dec 1, 2009 04:30PM by Torona I am new to the Dec. Rads group.  Just finished my 4 rounds of T/C on 11/16 and I'm scheduled for the Rads simulation trial on 12/9 with Rads tx to start on 12/10 for a total of 33.  I am like you, Jules, I am worried about the lung.  Because my tumor is very high upon my left chest (well above the breast) the rads onc said he would probably get the top of my lung but I wouldn't know it if he didn't tell me.  Well, he did and now I'm worried about long term effects.  I, too, am blonde (well, I used to be), light skinned and burn easily. I have had severe burns and allergic reactions at the IV sites where my chemo was given (didn't get port with only 4) so I'm already dealing with that. I have gained about 12 lbs. (they say from the steroids) and I want to start losing it, but didn't know if I could while getting radiation.  Anyone have good advice?  Hope to learn as much from this thread as I have all the others.  It's truly been a life saver for me.
Posts.Title: December 2009 Rads Group Linda_NJ BonnieSF

Posts.Title: December 2009 Rads Group Linda_NJ BonnieSF

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2009 08:35AM Torona wrote: Mimi, the article about the red wine research that I read said to drink the wine the day before treatment.  Somanywomen is right about doing your own research, though.  I posted a web site on the first page of this thread as well as suggesting the google search.  I had been drinking 1 glass a day before bc for my heart and cholesterol, but haven't had any since Dx because of all the new studies suggesting more than 4 glasses per week puts women at higher risk for bc.  I am planning to drink 1 the night before all my rads though.  I'll drop back to 4/week after rads is over.  Sorry your wait was so long!  I thought I felt my breast/chest area stinging last night but the techs said I wouldn't feel anything until about week 5.  Thought is was my imagination!
Posts.Title: December 2009 Rads Group Linda_NJ BonnieSF

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2009 07:27PM Torona wrote: My simulation (trial run) yesterday was pretty good.  The hardest part was lying perfectly still with my arms over my head and they went to sleep. Techs used a Christmas green permanent marker for the mapping and the X's!  I also got to see the Rad Onc and asked all my questions.  No vitamins or antioxidants, can continue my calcium and Omega 3 fish oil, no deodrant with aluminum but can use on the radiated side, not to gain or lose excessive weight, no holding breath while being zapped, just breathe normally, no creams or lotions until I start to burn then can use 100% aloe vera.  I am also planning to use the Lindi Skin Cooling pads and drinking a glass of red wine every night before my treatment since a new study showed red wine reduced toxicity and burning during radiation. My entire visit was 1 hour.  Pleasantly surprised with their efficiency. I had my 1st of 33 treatments today and I was in and out in 15 minutes. Really easy and no problems.  Techs said I probably wouldn't see any redness for about 5 weeks.  I go every week day at 4:00 p.m. so I can come home and rest afterwards.  So far so good. Hope everyone else is doing okay.
Posts.Title: December 2009 Rads Group Linda_NJ BonnieSF

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2009 06:19PM - edited Dec 3, 2009 06:34PM by Torona  Tried copying the link again, since one above didn't work right.  Hope you can get to it. http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/32648681/ns/health-cancer/  Edit: if above link doesn't work just google " radiation treatment for breast cancer and wine" and you'll get several articles.
Posts.Title: December 2009 Rads Group Linda_NJ BonnieSF

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2009 07:30PM Torona wrote: Just signed up today myself and I'm searching for a lot of answers on this website.  I would say "Ditto" to everything already posted.  I am still waiting on my Oncotype DX scores and had a lumpectomy 3 weeks ago.  The waiting is horrible, but I found that the time between each MRI, CT scan, surgery, Oncologist appointment, another MRI to rule out liver lesion, etc. helped me digest each new piece of information so that I'd be ready for the next wave of information.  I don't think I could have handled all of it hitting me at once - I'm not sure I would have make good decisions.  It is so much easier to deal with the actual facts than "imagining" the worst!  I found a web site called caringbridge.org that I have used to keep all my family, friends and loved ones up to date on my story and my journey with breast cancer.  You can also get messages from people without having to talk to each one individually.  It has been a life-saver for me.  You should check it out!  Good luck and know that we are all in this together!
Posts.Title: I just can't deal with this Sparrow one-L

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2009 06:17PM Torona wrote: Anyone read the articles that came out in the fall that drinking red wine before radiation may have less burning of skin?  I found an article on msn so I thought I'd send the link in case anyone is interested.  I plan on starting to drink a small glass before I start on Dec. 10. I was drinking a glass every day (for heart) before the bc diagnosis but haven't had any since I started chemo.   http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/32648681/ns/health-cancer/

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2009 07:35PM Torona wrote: I second all the posts above from running into 2010 with insurance stuff to the "tingling" sensation I have had in my radiated breast area since the 1st one.  I asked about it today and the techs said it was normal to feel anything from stinging to sharp pains.  At least I know something is coming out of that machine since you can't "see" anything.  I, too, am getting weary from all the things that I have gone through since June 2009 but I am looking forward to Christmas and spending time with my family.  I hope I won't be feeling too tired then.  My son and his wife are coming from Florida to spend it with me so I'm excited about that.  Maybe the "break" from rads during Christmas will help. My hair is coming back in but it looks totally grey now and I had very little grey before.  I should be glad that it is coming back in but I didn't want it to be grey.  I hope everyone does well though Christmas!
Posts.Title: December 2009 Rads Group Linda_NJ BonnieSF

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2009 05:48PM Torona wrote: I will be doing Rads in November so was reading this post to see what I could learn and it's been great!  I still have 2 more T/C of chemo yet but wanted to share a product I bought from Lindi. It's called a Skin Cooler.  It comes in a roll that you deep in the fridge and cut to the size you need to apply to radiated area following rads 20-45 minutes.  I don't know if it works or not.  I found mine at a Women's boutique but I'm attaching a link if anyone is interested www.lindiskin.com.  Every little bit of advice is so beneficial.  I too, read the recent study about 1 glass of wine before rad keeps your skin from burning.  Good luck!
